original.definition: take up a liquid or a gas either by adsorption or by absorption

sememes.reasoning: The verb 'sorb' describes a process where one substance incorporates another (a liquid or gas), leading to a change in the composition or internal state of the sorbing material.

participants.reasoning: The first 'Something' in the frame is the material that actively takes up the liquid or gas, thereby causing a change in its own composition.
The second 'something' in the frame refers to the liquid or gas that is taken up, undergoing a change of state by being incorporated.

Evidentiality.reasoning: Sorption is a physical process that is directly observable or verifiable through experimentation.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, stating a physical process.

Modality.reasoning: The 'Something' performing the action is an inanimate material and thus lacks will or intention.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of sorbing is a neutral scientific process; its outcome can be positive or negative depending on context but is not inherently so.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Something ----s something' indicates an inanimate subject, making the action inherently non-volitional.

Confidence.reasoning: The verb describes a definite physical phenomenon or occurrence.

Iterativity.reasoning: The lexeme 'sorb' typically refers to a single event of taking up a substance, or a process viewed as a single instance of completion, rather than repeated discrete actions.

participants.reasoning: value_type 'liquid_or_gas.n.01' is not a valid synset in NLTK.

candidates.description: a pump that draws air or another gas through a liquid (gloss match)
any of various devices in which air or some other gas is bubbled through a liquid (gloss match)
a flexible pipe for conveying a liquid or gas (gloss match)
a laboratory apparatus for producing a gas (usually hydrogen sulfide) by the action of a liquid on a solid without heating (gloss match)
a pipe used to transport liquids or gases (gloss match)
a large (usually metallic) vessel for holding gases or liquids (gloss match)
a freight car that transports liquids or gases in bulk (gloss match)
conduit consisting of a long hollow object (usually cylindrical) used to hold and conduct objects or liquids or gases (gloss match)
a meter to measure the volume of gases, liquids, or solids (either directly or by displacement) (gloss match)
a distensible membranous sac (usually containing liquid or gas) (gloss match)
the noise produced by the sudden rush of a fluid (a gas or liquid) (gloss match)
the motion characteristic of fluids (liquids or gases) (gloss match)
a cloud of solid or liquid particles in a gas (gloss match)
the random motion of small particles suspended in a gas or liquid (gloss match)
heat liberated by a unit mass of gas at its boiling point as it condenses into a liquid (gloss match)
unstable flow of a liquid or gas (gloss match)
flow of a gas or liquid in which the velocity at any point is relatively steady (gloss match)
the process of changing from a gaseous to a liquid or solid state (gloss match)
the transfer of heat through a fluid (liquid or gas) caused by molecular motion (gloss match)
changing from an adsorbed state on a surface to a gaseous or liquid state (gloss match)
the conversion of a solid or a gas into a liquid (gloss match)
a change from one state (solid or liquid or gas) to another without a change in chemical composition (gloss match)
any tiny hole admitting passage of a liquid (fluid or gas) (gloss match)

(physical chemistry) a fourth state of matter distinct from solid or liquid or gas and present in stars and fusion reactors; a gas becomes a plasma when it is heated until the atoms lose all their electrons, leaving a highly electrified collection of nuclei and free electrons (gloss match)

a highly poisonous gas or volatile liquid that smells like bitter almonds; becomes a gas at around 90 degree Fahrenheit and is most dangerous when inhaled; the anhydride of hydrocyanic acid; used in manufacturing (gloss match)
a substance for packing a joint or coating a porous surface to make it impervious to gas or liquid (gloss match)
a heavy colorless insoluble liquid compound that causes tears and vomiting; used as a pesticide and as tear gas (gloss match)
a fluid agent (gas or liquid) that produces cooling; especially one used to cool a system by transferring heat away from one part to another (gloss match)
a small discrete mass of solid or liquid matter that remains individually dispersed in gas or liquid emissions (usually considered to be an atmospheric pollutant) (gloss match)
the product of filtration; a gas or liquid that has been passed through a filter (gloss match)
continuous amorphous matter that tends to flow and to conform to the outline of its container: a liquid or a gas (gloss match)
a poisonous gas or liquid (CH3Br) used to fumigate rodents, worms, etc. (gloss match)

a highly lethal nerve agent used in chemical warfare; a toxic liquid that penetrates the skin or lungs to disrupt the nervous system and stop respiration; in combat VX gas is deployed by detonating a container over the target area and can persist in the environment up to several weeks after release (gloss match)
a mixture of sodium and calcium hydroxides; absorbs liquids and gases (gloss match)
the first known nerve agent, synthesized by German chemists in 1936; a highly toxic combustible liquid that is soluble in organic solvents and is used as a nerve gas in chemical warfare (gloss match)
